passage_text: The 2012 United States Senate election in Pennsylvania was held on November 6, 2012, alongside a presidential election, other elections to the United States Senate in other states, as well as elections to the United States House of Representatives and various state and local elections. Casey led most pre-election polls and eventually defeated his opponents to win re-election to a second term in the U.S. Senate. In so doing, Casey became the first Democratic Senator from Pennsylvania elected to a second term in 50 years.

In January 2012, the Pennsylvania Republican Party officially endorsed Steve Welch for U.S. Senate. The largest state newspaper, Philadelphia Inquirer, also endorsed Welch. Casey led most pre-election polls and eventually defeated his opponents to win re-election to a second term in the U.S. Senate. In so doing, Casey became the first Democratic Senator from Pennsylvania elected to a second term in 50 years.

Incumbent Democratic U.S. Senator Bob Casey, Jr. ran for and won re-election to a second term, defeating Republican nominee Tom Smith, and Libertarian nominee Rayburn Smith. The requisite primary elections occurred on April 24, 2012, during which the Republicans and Democrats selected nominees for the general election. Casey led most pre-election polls and eventually defeated his opponents to win re-election to a second term in the U.S. Senate. In so doing, Casey became the first Democratic Senator from Pennsylvania elected to a second term in 50 years.

Democrat Tom Wolf defeated incumbent Tom Corbett (R) in the 2014 Pennsylvania governor race. Corbett was first elected as governor of Pennsylvania in 2010. He struggled to keep support of GOP voters as his re-election race drew closer. In 2012, Corbett brought state funding for education back up to 2008 levels, still at least $500 million below the previous year without the stimulus funds. This fiscal year, Pennsylvania is spending $5.5 billion on basic education.

The current Junior U.S. Senator from Pennsylvania is Republican Pat Toomey. He was sworn into the Office of U.S. Senator on January 3rd, 2011. Pat Toomey is 53 years old and serving his first elected term as U.S. Senator. His Pennsylvania senatorial seat will be up for regular election on November 8th, 2016. He was sworn into the Office of Governor on January 20th, 2015. Tom Wolf is 66 years old and serving his first elected term as Governor. His Pennsylvania Gubernatorial seat will be up for regular election on November 6th, 2018. Tom Wolf is eligible for re-election in 2018 but has not yet announced his candidacy.

Governor of Pennsylvania The current Governor of Pennsylvania is Democrat Tom Wolf. He was sworn into the Office of Governor on January 20th, 2015. Tom Wolf is 66 years old and serving his first elected term as Governor. His Pennsylvania Gubernatorial seat will be up for regular election on November 6th, 2018. Tom Wolf is eligible for re-election in 2018 but has not yet announced his candidacy.

Election, Primary & Filing Dates: Primary: April 26, 2016 Filing Deadline: ~ February 2015 (Dem/Rep) ~ August 2016 (Third Parties & Independents). Poll Opening & Closing Times: In the state of Pennsylvania, all polls are open from 7:00 AM to 8:00 PM Eastern Time. Republican Caucus | Democratic Caucus Pennsylvania has 50 State Senate members: 23 (Democrats), 27 (Republicans). Length of term: 4 years. Republican Caucus | Democratic Caucus Pennsylvania has 203 State House members: 92 (Democrats), 110 (Republicans), 1 Vacant. Length of term: 2 years.

By ABC NEWS. Danny Johnston/AP Photo. Six states held primaries on Tuesday-Arkansas, Georgia, Idaho, Kentucky, Oregon, and Pennsylvania-in what turned out to be a Super Tuesday lite of the 2014 midterm election cycle. Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell bested Tea Party challenger Matt Bevin in Kentucky.

The 2012 election would also become the first time a Democrat won re-election to the U.S. Senate from Pennsylvania since the 1962 election. Casey led most pre-election polls and eventually defeated his opponents to win re-election to a second term in the U.S. Senate. In so doing, Casey became the first Democratic Senator from Pennsylvania elected to a second term in 50 years.
